newsitem.title: ROMANIA: ROMANIA GVT DENIES PLANS TO CHANGE C.BANK CHIEF.
newsitem.headline: ROMANIA GVT DENIES PLANS TO CHANGE C.BANK CHIEF.

text.p: The government on Thursday said it was not considering any change of the leadership of Romania's central bank (BNR) after the bank denied a newspaper report that its governor, Mugur Isarescu, would soon step down.
"The government has not discussed a change of the National Bank governor, and there has been no criticism, at least so far, regarding BNR policies," a government spokesman said.
"A change of Mugur Isarescu has not figured on the agenda of any cabinet meeting."
The daily Evenimentul Zilei said on Thursday that Isarescu, in an exclusive statement, had confirmed speculation that he was planning to quit his job before his mandate expired.
But the BNR denied the report.
"The statement in the newspaper is not the governor's," spokesman Adrian Vasilescu told Reuters.
Isarescu, one of the few Romanian officials who has remained in his position since the 1989 fall of communism, was appointed BNR governor in July 1991.
Under Romania's banking legislation, the term of office for the BNR governor is eight years.
Isarescu's links to the previously ruling ex-communists appear to be a possible motive for seeking his removal.
Isarescu managed under the leftist administration voted out of office last November to resist political pressure to put the BNR under government instead of parliamentary control.
Only parliament can remove Isarescu, but the centrist coalition holds a large majority in both houses.

Unlike the leftist government he served under, Isarescu enjoys a good international reputation. He was criticised as long ago as 1994 for adopting tough monetary policy and taking steps to clear the banking sector of debt-ridden banks.
He acknowledged that his bank was forced by the former leftist administration to relax policies and print money ahead of last year's election.
